_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The chlorine system at the City of San Clemente Utilities Division Water Reclamation Facility is used for the treatment of wastewater.  The Water Reclamation Facility uses chlorine for odor control, filamentous control, and disinfection at the various stages of the treatment processes:  1) chlorine contact basins, 2) headworks prechlorination, 3) Return Activated Sludge (RAS), and 4) solids handing hypochlorite scrubber.  As stated on their website, ?The purpose of the City Utilities Division is to ensure uninterrupted water, sewer, and drainage service to all our customers that meet all regulatory requirements.?

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Startup of the chlorine system occurred in 1988.  The process is located at 380 Avenida Pico, San Clemente, California 92672.  The chlorine system for the Water Reclamation Facility of City of San Clemente Utilities Division consists of chlorine one-ton containers which are the storage vessels.  Chlorine gas is drawn from a maximum of four tanks on line through a vacuum regulator to the chlorinators.  Still under vacuum from the chlorinators, it is drawn to injectors and mixed with water from the treatment processes.

The maximum quantity of chlorine that can be stored on site is 16,000 pounds.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The chlorine system at the Water Reclamation Facility has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the City of San Clemente Utilities Division treatment processes operate in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  This includes common practices outlined by the Chlo

rine Institute.

In the event that the primary engineering or administration controls at the Water Reclamation Facility fail and result in a release of chlorine, there are three mechanisms in the facility to minimize the impact: 1) chlorine sensors/detectors, 2) visual/audible alarms, and 3) emergency chlorine scrubber system.  The chlorine sensors that trigger audible and visual alarms are located in the chlorine storage room and chlorinator room.  Upon detection of 1 ppm of chlorine, the chlorine detector light comes on.  Once a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm is detected by the sensors, the audible/visual alarm sounds and the ventilation system that continuously circulates the air in the building will be shut off by the scrubber system.  The chlorine scrubber system then will absorb and will reduce the chlorine concentration of the chlorine storage room.  The operator on duty will then be paged.

The emergency chlorine scrubber system at the Water Reclamation Facility system uses a horizontal packed bed and exhaust fan design to reduce the concentration of chlorine within the chlorine storage room to 0.5 ppm.  As the chlorine laden gases pass through each of the stages, chlorine is absorbed and reacted with caustic solution and chlorine free air is exhausted through the stack. The system is designed with the ventilation rate of 3,000 ACFM air flow rate and the maximum discharge chlorine concentration of 5 ppm.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An investigation into the facility?s accident history revealed that in the last five years (May 2004 ? May 2009), there have been no releases of chlorine that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 10 pounds or the California threshold of ?any? release at the Water Reclamation Facility of City of San Clemente Utilities Division.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from chlorine release, nor any releases or ?near misses? that warranted an internal incident investigation.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The City

of San Clemente Utilities Division has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives: 

1.) To save lives.
2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.) To protect the environment.
4.) To minimize property damage.

City of San Clemente Utilities Division is a designated non-responding facility.  The Emergency Action Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, chlorine health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.   This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations, and to ensure that the plan is kept current. The Emergency Response Plan is regularly reviewed and updated by the City of San Clemente Utilities Division Water Reclamation Facility responsible person

The Plan also includes the Emergency training for all City of San Clemente Utilities Division employees.  The City of San Clemente Utilities Division performs periodic emergency evacuation drills to enhance the emergency response skills of its personnel.

The City of San Clemente Utilities Division has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department, Orange County Fire Authority.  In the case of a chlorine-related emergency, it is the policy of City of San Clemente Utilities Division to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department to respond to the emergency (potentially with the assistance of trained facility personnel).  There is a windsock present on the building to ensure that the responder is approaching from the upwind direction.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Revalidation provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the City of San Clemente Utilities Division W

ater Reclamation Facility.  The PHA Revalidation was comprised of one session that included a discussion of any changes to the chlorine system since the 2004 PHA Revalidation and the 2008 PSM/RMP/CalARP Three-Year Compliance Audit, a detailed review of the recommended action items generated during the 2004 PHA Revalidation, PSM/RMP/CalARP Program Recommendation Summary ? Action Plan (In response to OCFA letter dated July 3, 2001), and 2004/2008  PSM/RMP/CalARP Three-Year Compliance Audit, a discussion of the facility's accident history dating back five years, the review of chlorine checklists, and a site inspection to review seismic issues.  The changes are scheduled to be completed by May 2010.

In addition, the facility is planning to complete several items over the next year as their continued effort to provide a safe work environment for the Water Reclamation Facility employees.  These changes include the following items:

1.  Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility's safety programs.

2.  Continue to have employee involvement in updating and refining Process Safety Management and the facility's safety programs.

3.  Continue employee involvement through the Employee Participation program.

4.  Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
